content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one. Here is my solution in python:

from collections import defaultdict

n = int(input())
anagrams = defaultdict(list)

for i in range(n):
    row = input()
    key = "".join(sorted(row))
    anagrams[key].append(row)

lines = [" ".join(sorted(grams))for grams in anagrams.values() if len(grams) > 1]
print(*sorted(lines),sep='\n')

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easily solvable in under 5 minutes, and I'd say a good clash

Good one!

Another comment on the wording: "the first word in each line should be in alphabetical order" does not make a lot of sense in English, as one word cannot be in any order.

I would rephrase the Output section something along this way: "One line for each set of anagrams. Lines must be printed in alphabetical order. Words in each line must also be sorted alphabetically"

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle!

Can we say "The first word in each..." instead of "The first words in each..."?
Good point, I made the change.
Yeah, the wording was awkward.  Does it look okay now?

Much better. Approving ✅

Edit: never mind - the description is OK, but I'm not really happy with the complexity. It requires optimization, which IMHO is not really suitable for clashes. I would either drastically reduce the last test's set or do away with it completely.
(not sure if you get notified for edited comments so posting another reply)
Hmmm, what needs to be optimized?  Sorting 1000 items isn't going to time out.

No, but checking 1000 items vs 1000 items is, and that is the simplest way to check for anagrams that came to my mind. Sure you can think of more sophisticated ones, but IMHO that is already stepping in the optimisation territory. The way I understand clash challenges, they should be compatible with the idea of a "hasty solution that works".

Let me reverse the question: why do you need to test against a large data set? what does it bring to the tests that is not covered by the others?

Well, I mean if you did something extremely slow like that maybe the 500 and 200 cases are too big as well in some language.  I think it is reasonable as is, the text is short to read so there is plenty of time and I don't see many going for that kind of approach.

I did :) and I'm not sure I could come up with anything better under the pressure of the time.

Again, I would like to ask you: what value does the large data set bring to the tests? What purpose does it serve, that is not served by the others?
It just seems less fun somehow if I make then all less than 100 words :).  If others have the same complaint I will change it.
